# About-Soil

<h1>
<hr>
<font color="black">
<align="center">
<sub>
Soil profil
</sub>
<hr>
</align>
<p>
<h1><u>Sandy soil</u></h1>
<img src="data:image/jpeg;base64,"/><br>
Sandy Soil is light, warm, dry and tends to be acidic and low in nutrients.<br> Sandy soils are often known as light soils due to their high proportion of sand and little clay (clay weighs more than sand).<br>

These soils have quick water drainage and are easy to work with.<br>
 They are quicker to warm up in spring than clay soils but tend to dry out in summer and suffer from low nutrients that are washed away by rain.<br>

The addition of organic matter can help give plants an additional boost of nutrients by improving the nutrient and water holding capacity of the soil.<br>

<H1><u>Clayey soil</u> </h1>

<img src="data:image/jpeg;base64,"/><p>Clay Soil is a heavy soil type that benefits from high nutrients.<br> Clay soils remain wet and cold in winter and dry out in summer.<br>

These soils are made of over 25 percent clay, and because of the spaces found between clay particles, clay soils hold a high amount of water.<br>

Because these soils drain slowly and take longer to warm up in summer, combined with drying out and cracking in summer, they can often test gardeners.

<h1><u>Silt soil</u></h1>
<img src="data:image/jpeg;base64,"/><br>
<p>Silt Soil is a light and moisture retentive soil type with a high fertility rating.<br>

As silt soils compromise of medium sized particles they are well drained and hold moisture well.<br>

As the particles are fine, they can be easily compacted and are prone to washing away with rain.<br>

By adding organic matter, the silt particles can be bound into more stable clumps.</p>

<H1><u>Peat soil</u></H1>

<img src="data:image/jpeg;base64,"/><br>
<p>Peat soil is high in organic matter and retains a large amount of moisture.<br>

This type of soil is very rarely found in a garden and often imported into a garden to provide an optimum soil base for planting.<br>

<h1><u>Chalk soil</u></h1>

<img src="data:image/jpeg;base64,"/><br>
<pChalk soil can be either light or heavy but always highly alkaline due to the calcium carbonate (lime) within its structure.<br>

As these soils are alkaline they will not support the growth of ericaceous plants that require acidic soils to grow.<br>

If a chalky soil shows signs of visible white lumps then they cant be acidified and gardeners should be resigned to only choose plants that prefer an alkaline soil.<br>

<h1><u>Lomany soil</u></h1>

<img src="data:image/jpeg;base64,"/>
<p>Loam soil is a mixture of sand, silt and clay that are combined to avoid the negative effects of each type.<br>

These soils are fertile, easy to work with and provide good drainage.<br> Depending on their predominant composition they can be either sandy or clay loam.<br>

As the soils are a perfect balance of soil particles, they are considered to be a gardeners best friend, but still benefit from topping up with additional organic matter.<br>

</BODY>
